sn7.22:4.2: “Great King, this one time I was staying in the land of the Sakyans where they have a town named Nagaraka.
sn7.22:4.3: Then the Buddha got dressed in the morning and, taking his bowl and robes, entered Khomadussa for alms.
sn7.22:4.4: Now at that time the brahmins and householders of Khomadussa were gathered in the council hall for some business, while a gentle rain drizzled down.
sn7.22:4.5: Then the Buddha approached that council.
sn7.22:4.6: The brahmins and householders saw the Buddha coming off in the distance,
sn7.22:4.8: “Who are these baldies, these fake ascetics? Don’t they understand the council rules?”
sn7.22:4.9: Then the Buddha addressed the brahmins and householders of Khomadussa in verse:
sn7.22:5.1: “If good people are not present it is no true council;
sn7.22:5.2: and those whose speak against principle are not good people.
sn7.22:5.3: Having given up greed, hate, and delusion,
sn7.22:5.4: speakers of principle are good people.”
sn7.22:6.1: When he had spoken, the brahmins and householders of Khomadussa said to the Buddha:
sn7.22:6.3: As if he was righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark
sn7.22:6.4: so people with good eyes can see what’s there,
sn7.22:6.5: Master Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.
sn7.22:6.6: We go for refuge to Master Gotama, to the Dharma, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
sn7.22:6.7: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember us as lay followers who have gone for refuge for life.”
sn7.22:9.1: The Linked Discourses with brahmins are complete.
